description: From Middle English snoren, fnoren (“to snore loudly; snort”), from Middle English snore, *fnore (“snore; snort”, noun), from Old English fnora (“snort; sneezing”), from Proto-Germanic *fnuzô, from Proto-Indo-European *pnew- (“to breathe; snort; sneeze”). Compare also Proto-West Germanic *snarkōn, Middle Low German snorren (“to drone”), Dutch snorren (“to hum, purr”).
The change fn → sn in this word is regular, seen also in sneeze, from Middle English fnesen (see that entry for more).

entries.meaning: The act of snoring, and the noise produced.
(informal) An extremely boring person or event.

verbs.description: snore (third-person singular simple present snores, present participle snoring, simple past and past participle snored)

entries.meaning: To breathe during sleep with harsh, snorting noises caused by vibration of the soft palate.
